ol.li: The most general form of a second-degree equation in two variables is Ax^2 + Bxy + Cy^2 + Dx + Ey + F = 0 where A, B, and C cannot all be zero, and its graph is a conic section.
An ellipse is the set of points in the plane the sum of whose distances from two fixed points (called the foci) is a constant.
The standard form for an ellipse centered at the origin is \dfrac{x^2}{a^2} + \dfrac{y^2}{b^2} = 1
A hyperbola is the set of points in the plane, the difference of whose distances from two fixed points (the foci) is a constant.

The standard form for a hyperbola centered at the origin with foci on the x-axis is \dfrac{x^2}{a^2} - \dfrac{y^2}{b^2} = 1 The standard form for a hyperbola centered at the origin with foci on the y-axis is \dfrac{y^2}{b^2} - \dfrac{x^2}{a^2} = 1
We can draw the asymptotes by first forming the "central rectangle," whose sides pass through the vertices and covertices. The asymptotes are the diagonals of this rectangle.
A parabola is the set of points in the plane whose distances from a fixed line l and a fixed point F are equal.

Parabolas with vertex at the origin have equations of the form y=\dfrac{x^2}{4p} ~~~~~~ \text{or} ~~~~~~ y=\dfrac{-x^2}{4p} ~~~~~~ \text{or} ~~~~~~ x=\dfrac{y^2}{4p} ~~~~~~ \text{and} ~~~~~~ x=\dfrac{-y^2}{4p}
The standard equation for an ellipse centered at (h,k) is \dfrac{(x-h)^2}{a^2} + \dfrac{(y-k)^2}{b^2} = 1
Second-degree equations can be written in one of the standard forms by completing the square.
To write the equation of an ellipse from a description of its properties, we must find the center of the ellipse and the lengths of its axes.
The standard equations for a hyperbola centered (h,k) at are \dfrac{(x-h)^2}{a^2} - \dfrac{(y-k)^2}{b^2} = 1~~\text{and}~~\dfrac{(y-k)^2}{b^2} - \dfrac{(x-h)^2}{a^2} = 1

The standard equation for a parabola with vertex at has one of the following forms. y-k=a(x-h)^2~~~~~\text{opens upward if}~a \gt 0;~~\text{downward if}~a \lt 0 x-h=a(y-k)^2~~~~~\text{opens to the right if}~a \gt 0;~~\text{to the left if}~a \lt 0
The constant a is equal to \dfrac{\pm1}{4p}, where p is the distance between the vertex and the focus of the parabola.
The coefficients D, E, and F do not affect the type of conic section the equation represents, but they do determine the position of the graph relative to the origin.
The graph of a second-degree equation in two variables is a conic section.

li.p: The graph of ~Ax^2 + Bxy + Cy^2 + Dx + Ey + F = 0~ is

ol.li: a circle if A=C.
a parabola if A=0 or C=0 (but not both).
an ellipse if A \not= C and they have the same sign.
a hyperbola if A and C have opposite signs.
Systems involving conics may have up to four solutions.
To solve some quadratic systems, we can use a combination of elimination of variables and substitution.
